images.title: Private suites

longDescription: Lichen sclerosus can cause burning, itching, whitened patches, and painful intimacy. Our female programme blends anti-inflammatory platelet-rich plasma (PRP) injections, red/near-infrared LED therapy, prescription barrier creams, and microbiome support to heal micro-tears and reduce flare frequency.\n\nConsultations take place in private suites with optional female chaperones. We document changes with encrypted photography only when you consent, monitor hormones and autoimmune markers, and provide digital flare diaries so you can message the clinic discreetly between appointments.
tagline: Calm Flares. Repair Tissue. Protect Comfort.

overview.content: We begin with a gentle exam, hormone review, and swabs or biopsy if needed. Treatment blends PRP to thicken fragile skin, LED therapy to reduce inflammation, compounded topicals to repair the barrier, and guidance on hygiene, clothing, and supplements. You’ll leave with a clear plan for daily care and flare management.
overview.title: Holistic Management for a Chronic Condition

title: Female Lichen Sclerosus Relief Programme

seo.metaTitle: Female Lichen Sclerosus Treatment London | Dr. SNA Clinic
seo.metaDescription: Specialist care for female lichen sclerosus: PRP, LED therapy, prescription topicals, and lifestyle guidance in a discreet medical clinic.

schema.howPerformed: After applying topical numbing cream to ensure comfort, we draw a small amount of blood from your arm (10ml) and process it in a sterile dual-spin centrifuge to create concentrated platelet-rich plasma. Using ultra-fine needles, we inject this golden PRP into affected vulvar tissue—targeting areas of whitening, thinning, or scarring. Each injection delivers growth factors that thicken fragile skin and improve blood flow. Immediately after, you receive medical-grade LED therapy: red (630nm) and near-infrared (850nm) light panels are positioned over the treatment area for 15 minutes to reduce inflammation. The entire session takes 45 minutes. We photograph progress (encrypted, with consent only) and provide custom barrier creams and hygiene kits
schema.preparation: Come with clean, dry skin—no lotions or creams on vulvar area day of treatment. Shower beforehand if comfortable. Wear loose, comfortable clothing (skirt or loose trousers work well). If you're experiencing a flare, notify us—we may adjust timing. Stop anti-inflammatory medications (ibuprofen) 3 days before if safe. Bring any recent biopsy reports, dermatology letters, or photos documenting your symptoms. Female chaperones available on request. Come ready to discuss intimate symptoms openly in a judgment-free, clinical environment
schema.followup: Apply the prescribed barrier cream twice daily as directed—this is critical for maintaining moisture and preventing micro-tears. Avoid tight underwear, synthetic fabrics, and harsh soaps for one week. Treated areas may feel slightly warm or puffy for 24-48 hours (ice packs help). Avoid sexual activity for 48 hours to allow healing. Continue LED sessions as scheduled (usually 4 sessions over 2 weeks). Log symptoms in your digital flare diary so we can monitor progress. Attend your 2-week and 6-week reviews—we'll assess tissue color, texture, and comfort. Most women reduce steroid frequency significantly after first PRP session. Maintenance LED or PRP boosters every 3-6 months keep inflammation controlled long-term
schema.outcome: Within the first week, itching and burning typically calm as inflammation reduces. Over 4-8 weeks, whitened patches gradually regain healthier pink tone. Skin becomes thicker, more elastic, and less prone to tearing during intimacy. Many women report comfortable sexual activity for the first time in years. Dependence on potent steroid creams decreases dramatically—you'll use them only during occasional flares rather than daily. The tissue architecture is protected, reducing risk of fusion, stenosis, or progression to severe scarring. Confidence returns as you regain control over symptoms. Results last 6-12 months with proper maintenance, and you can repeat treatment as needed. This is about managing a chronic condition with dignity and hope
schema.medicationRequired: Topical numbing cream (lidocaine 5%). Optional prescribed barrier creams containing clobetasol or tacrolimus for home maintenance
schema.treatmentFrequency: Two PRP sessions spaced 4 weeks apart for initial treatment, plus 4 LED sessions over those 8 weeks. Maintenance PRP or LED boosters every 3-6 months depending on symptom control and flare frequency
schema.adverseOutcome: Mild warmth, redness, or swelling in treated areas for 24-48 hours (normal healing response). Possible small bruise at blood draw site. Temporary increased sensitivity for first 24 hours. Very rarely, infection at injection site (we use strict sterile technique)

seriousAdverseOutcome.name: Allergic reaction to barrier creams or worsening of symptoms
seriousAdverseOutcome.probability: Very rare (less than 1%) when treatments are individualized and monitored closely

contraindication: Active genital infection or open sores requiring antibiotics first
Bleeding disorders or taking anticoagulants without medical clearance
Uncontrolled autoimmune conditions without dermatologist/rheumatologist clearance
Unwillingness to follow maintenance regimen (consistency is critical)
typicalTest: Vulvar biopsy (if diagnosis uncertain or ruling out malignancy)
Microbiome swabs to check for bacterial/yeast overgrowth
Hormone panel (estrogen, testosterone) especially perimenopausal patients
Autoimmune screening (ANA, thyroid antibodies) if systemic symptoms
Encrypted photography for objective progress tracking
clinicalFindings: Vulvar lichen sclerosus with itching, burning, or pain
Visible whitening, thinning, or architectural changes of vulvar tissue
Painful intercourse from fragile, inelastic tissue
Recurrent tearing or fissures in vulvar area
Post-surgical patients wanting to protect remaining tissue
Desire to prevent progression to fusion or stenosis

howItWorks.title: Regeneration Meets Anti-Inflammatory Light
howItWorks.subtitle: Why PRP + LED calm LS
howItWorks.content: PRP releases growth factors (PDGF, VEGF, EGF) that speed up healing, thicken the epidermis, and improve microcirculation. LED therapy at 630 nm and 830 nm reduces inflammatory cytokines and supports melanocyte balance. Together they minimise itching, restore colour, and protect tissue from tearing.

benefits.title: Anti-Inflammatory
benefits.description: LED down-regulates TNF-α and IL-6 for calmer skin.

benefits.title: Tissue Repair
benefits.description: PRP thickens skin and improves resilience.

description: Doctor-led PRP, LED light therapy, and barrier repair plans that soothe vulvar lichen sclerosus and prevent long-term scarring.

comparisons.duration: Permanent but may not stop recurrence

faq.question: Do I still need steroids?
faq.answer: Yes, but usually only during flares. Our programme reduces frequency and reliance on potent creams.

faq.question: Will PRP cure LS?
faq.answer: LS is chronic; PRP and LED keep it in remission, protect tissue, and lessen symptoms.
Many patients avoid excision when inflammation is controlled. We coordinate with your gynaecologist if surgery is recommended.
faq.question: Can I remain uncircumcised/avoid surgery?
Is PRP safe?
faq.answer: PRP is your own blood processed sterilely. Side effects are limited to temporary redness or warmth.
Most women return every 3-6 months for LED or booster PRP depending on severity.
faq.question: How often do I need maintenance?
Can LS increase cancer risk?
faq.answer: Chronic inflammation can raise risk slightly. Regular monitoring and treatment reduce that risk. We coordinate smears and biopsies when needed.
